Question.Text: A 14-year-old boy presents to a clinic in Malawi with necrotic wound on his right foot. He was bitten by a snake 3 weeks earlier. Shortly after the bite, haemorrhagic bullae formed on the right leg. His gums started to bleed and he vomited extensively.

Answer: Snake envenomation (viper bite) with local necrosis and coagulopathy - The patient presents with necrotic wound following snake bite 3 weeks ago, with hemorrhagic bullae, gingival bleeding, and vomiting in Malawi. The images show extensive tissue necrosis with black eschar and snake (likely puff adder or carpet viper), typical of viperid envenomation causing local cytotoxicity and systemic hemorrhagic coagulopathy.
